front.title: Requirements for IPv6 Customer Edge Routers

abstract.t: This document specifies requirements for an IPv6 Customer Edge (CE) router. Specifically, the current version of this document focuses on the provisioning of an IPv6 CE router and the provisioning of IPv6 hosts attached to it.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document defines IPv6 features for a residential or small office router referred to as an IPv6 CE router. Typically these routers also support IPv4. IPv4 support is not discussed any further in this document.

This document specifes how an IPv6 CE router automatically provisions its upstream interface, acquires an address block for provisioning of its downstream interfaces and fetches other configuration information from the service provider network. Automatic provisioning of more complex topology than a single router with multiple downstream interfaces is out of scope for this document. In IPv6 with the use of global addressing, addresses are inherently transient. The implication of that for a complex network topology with multiple levels of routers is that network wide address renumbering would have to be made automatic.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

A standalone or embedded IPv6 Internet gateway, intended for home or small office use, that routes IPv6 traffic from one or more LAN Interfaces to the Internet.
any device implementing an IPv6 stack receiving IPv6 Internet connectivity through the IPv6 CE router

a network interface on a link in the customer network. A LAN Interface could attach to Ethernet, IEEE 802.11, MoCA 1.0/1.1, and other networks. An IPv6 CE router may have one or more network interfaces

A company that offers its customers access to the Internet. In this document, a Service Provider specifically offers Internet access using IPv6, and may also offer IPv4 Internet access. The Service Provider can provide such access over a variety of different transport methods such as DSL, cable, wireless, and others.
the single physical network interface on the IPv6 CE router that is used to connect the router to the access network of the Service Provider.

section.title: Architecture
Current IPv4 end-user network architecture:
section.t: An end-user network will have to support both IPv4 and IPv6. It is not expected that the end-user will have to change the existing network topology with the introduction of IPv6. There are some differences in how IPv6 works and is provisioned which has implications for the network architecture. A typical IPv4 end-user network consist of a "plug and play" NAT box connected to the ISP. The assumption is a single NAT device with a single link behind it. The NAT provides stable addressing allowing for manually configured addresses on the nodes in the end-user network.

Apart from the expert user's arbitrary network topology another case is the unconventional use of "plug and play" NAT devices to build a hierarchical multi-level NAT topology (as described in Unintended Consequence of two NAT deployments with Overlapping Address Space). Multi-level NAT devices are provisioned and addressed automatically and as long as these are plugged in as a strict hierarchy it kind of works even though conventional network wisdom would tell you otherwise.
A typical IPv4 NAT deployment gives you by default blocking of all incoming connections. Opening of ports is typically allowed using UPnP or some other firewall control protocol.

Another consequence of using private address space in the end-user network is that it provides stable addressing, i.e. it never changes even when you change ISPs, and the addresses are always there even when the upstream link is down or the customer edge router has not been provisioned yet.
Rewriting addresses on the edge of the network also allows for some rudimentary multi-homing; even though using NATs for multi-homing does not preserve connections during fail-overs.
Existing routers support dynamic routing, and advanced end-user can build arbitrary complex networks. Using manual configuration of address prefixes combined with a dynamic routing protocol.

section.section:
The end-user network architecture for IPv6 should provide equivalent or better capabilities and functionality than the equivalent IPv4 architecture.
The end-user network is a stub network. Figure 1 illustrates the model topology for the end-user network.
An example of a typical end-user network.

This architecture describes the: Basic capabilities of an IPv6 CE router and internal router Provisioning of WAN interface connecting to the ISP Provisioning of the downstream interfaces
Issues which may be different in an IPv6 end-user network: Addresses in the network before the IPv6 CE router has been provisioned Renumbering of address prefix in the network because use of Provider Assigned global addresses Default security policy without NAT Support for coupling routers in a hierarchy, aka multi-level NATs
For the purposes of provisioning the address on its WAN interface the IPv6 CE router acts as a host using either SLAAC or DHCP. Other configuration information is acquired using DHCP as described in . The IPv6 CE router acts as a requesting router for the purposes of prefix delegation and always initiates prefix delegation according to .

The IPv6 CE router assigns a /64 from its delegated prefix(es) to each of its downstream LAN interfaces. It may also generate a Unique Local Address prefix [citation] and assign a ULA /64 prefix to each of its LAN interfaces for communciation within the home network.
IPv6 hosts acquire IPv6 addresses either through SLAAC or DHCP. The IPv6 CE router provides configuration information obtained from provisioning of the WAN interface to the hosts on the downstream interface(s) using DHCP.
The IPv6 CE router default to acting as the demarcation point between two networks and implements a ULA boundary, a multicast zone boundary as well as ingress and egress traffic filters.
For IPv6 multicast traffic the IPv6 CE router acts as an MLD proxy and may support a dynamic multicast routing protocol.
IPv6 CE router may be manually configured in an arbitrary topology with a dynamic routing protocol. Automatic provisioning and configuration is described for a single IPv6 CE router only.

section.title: IPv6 CE router WAN configuration
section.t: The IPv6 CE router will need to support connectivity to one or more access network architectures. This document describes a IPv6 CE router that is not specific to any particular architecture or service provider, and supports all commonly used architectures.

IPv6 Neighbor Discovery and DHCP protocols operate over any type of IPv6 supported link-layer and there is no need for a link-layer specific configuration protocol for IPv6 network layer configuration options like what's e.g. in PPP IPCP for IPv4. This section makes the assumption that the same mechanism will work for any link-layer, be it Ethernet, DOCSIS, PPP/PPPoE or others.

When the router is attached to the upstream link it must act as an IPv6 host for the purposes of IPv6 interface initialisation, neighbor discovery router discovery, prefix discovery and interface address assignment (RFC 4861/RFC 4862). The router acts as a requesting router for the purposes of DHCP prefix delegation (RFC 3633).

The IPV6 CE router will always initiate DHCP prefix delegation, regardless of the M and O-bits in a received Router Advertisement. On router-router links were RAs MAY not be used the IPv6 CE router should initiate DHCP PD even when an RA has not been received. Both address assignment and prefix delegation should be done within a single DHCP session.
Link-layer requirements: The IPv6 CE router MUST support IPv6 over Ethernet (RFC 2464). The IPv6 CE router MUST support IPv6 over PPP (RFC 5072). It MUST support use of IPv6 over PPP within PPPoE.

Address assignment requirements: The IPv6 CE router MUST support SLAAC ().
The IPv6 CE router MUST support DHCP client behavior. It MUST be able to support the following DHCP options: IA_NA, Reconfigure Accept(), DNS_SERVERS ().
Th IPv6 CE router SHOULD support the DHCP SNTP option ().
If the IPv6 CE router receives an RA message (described in ) with the M-bit set to 1, the IPv6 CE router MUST request an IA_NA. If the IPv6 CE router is unable to assign an address through SLAAC it MAY request an IA_NA even if the M-bit is set to 0.
If the IPv6 CE router does not acquire a global IPv6 address from either SLAAC or DHCP, then it MUST create a global IPv6 address from its delegated prefix and configure that on one of its internal interfaces.

Prefix Delegation requirements:
The IPv6 CE router MUST support DHCP prefix delegation requesting router behaviour as specified in RFC3633 (IA_PD option). The IPv6 CE router MUST ask for a prefix large enough to cover all of its LAN interfaces.
A null route SHOULD be added to the routing table for the delegated prefix (to prevent routing loops) that is lower priority than any route except the default route. The choice to drop the packet or send an ICMPv6 Destination Unreachable to the source address of the packet is implementation-dependent.
If the IPv6 CE router requests both an IA_NA and an IA_PD in DHCP, it MUST accept an IA_PD in DHCP Advertise/Reply messages, even if the message does not contain any addresses (IA_NA options with status code NoAddrsAvail).
The IPv6 CE MUST use router discovery as specified in RFC4861 and it MUST install default route(s) in its RIB for the list of default routers. If no Router Advertisement with a Router Lifetime greater than zero is received, the default route MUST be installed using the link-local source address of the PD delegating router as the next-hop.
An IPv6 CE router MUST not initiate any dynamic routing protocol on its WAN interface.

section.title: IPv6 CE router LAN configuration
section.t: The IPv6 CE router distributes configuration information obtained during WAN interface provisioning to IPv6 hosts and assists IPv6 hosts in obtaining IPv6 addresses. It also supports connectivity of these devices in the absence of any working WAN interface.
An IPv6 CE router will be expected to support an IPv6 end-user network and IPv6 hosts that exhibit the following characteristics:

list.t: Link-local addresses are insufficient for allowing IPv6 applications to communicate with each other in the end-user network. The IPv6 CE router will need to enable this communication by providing globally-scoped unicast addresses or ULAs whether or not WAN connectivity exists.
IPv6 hosts will be capable of using SLAAC and may be capable of using DHCP for acquiring their addresses.
IPv6 hosts will use DHCP for other configuration information, such as the DNS_SERVERS option for acquiring DNS information.

section.t:
Requirements: The IPv6 CE router MUST support ULA addressing (RFC4193). The IPv6 CE router MUST have a ULA prefix that it maintains consistently across reboots. The value of the ULA prefix SHOULD be user configurable.
The IPv6 CE router by default MUST act as a site border router according to section 4.3 of RFC4193 and filter packets with Local IPv6 source or destination addresses accordingly.
The IPv6 CE router MUST support router behavior of Neighbor Discovery for IPv6 (RFC4861). If the IPv6 CE router is configured to provide ULA addressing to IPv6 hosts, it MUST provide a /64 prefix from its ULA prefix in its RA message. This prefix MUST have A/L-bits set to 1 by default; this SHOULD be user configurable. The IPv6 CE router must assign a separate /64 from its delegated prefix for each of its LAN-interfaces. In router advertisements messages this prefix MUST have A/L-bits set to 1 by default; this SHOULD be user configurable.
The IPv6 CE router MUST support a DHCP server (RFC 3315) on its LAN interfaces. It SHOULD support DHCP address assignment (IA_NA). Unless the IPv6 CE router is configured to support DHCP IA_NA, it SHOULD set M=0 and O=1 in its RA messages. The IPv6 CE router MUST support providing DNS information in the DHCP DNS_SERVERS option (RFC3646). The IPv6 CE router SHOULD pass the additional set of DHCP options received from the DHCP client on its WAN interface from the Service Provider to IPv6 hosts.

section.title: IPv6 CE router
section.t: The IPv6 CE router is responsible for implementing IPv6 routing; that is, the IPv6 CE router must look up the IPv6 Destination address in its routing table to decide to which interface it should send the packet. The typical scenario for packets routed to the WAN Interface is that the next-hop router will be the CPE Router's default route, learned via Router Advertisement from the Service Provider router.
In this role, the IPv6 CE router is responsible for ensuring that traffic using its ULA addressing does not go out the WAN interface, and does not originate from the WAN interface.

Requirements: An IPv6 CE router is an IPv6 node and MUST follow the IPv6 Node Requirements specification. The IPv6 CE router may discover other devices on the network connected to the WAN interface using ND. Consistent with [RFC4943], unless the L bit in the RA is set to 1, the CPE Router SHOULD assume that such devices are "not-on-link", so traffic for such devices SHOULD be forwarded to the default router. The IPv6 CE router MUST NOT forward any IPv6 traffic between its LAN Interface(s) and its WAN Interface until the router has successfully completed the IPv6 address acquisition process.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: It is considered a best practice to filter obviously malicious traffic (e.g. spoofed packets, "martian" addresses, etc.). Thus, the IPv6 CE router should support basic stateless egress and ingress filters. The CE router should also offer mechanisms to filter traffic entering the customer network; however, the method by which vendors implement configurable packet filtering is beyond the scope of this document.
Security requirements: The IPv6 CE router SHOULD support I-D.ietf-v6ops-cpe-simple-security. The IPv6 CE router MUST support ingress filtering in accordance with (BCP 38)
